sn56.52:4.1: “Mendicants, suppose there was a lotus pond that was fifty leagues long, fifty leagues wide, and fifty leagues deep, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
sn56.52:4.2: Then a person would pick up some water on the tip of a blade of grass.
sn56.52:4.3: “What do you think, mendicants? Which is more:
sn56.52:4.4: the water on the tip of the blade of grass, or the water in the lotus pond?”
sn56.52:4.5: “Sir, the water in the lotus pond is certainly more.
sn56.52:4.7: The water on the tip of a blade of grass is tiny.
sn56.52:4.8: Compared to the water in the lotus pond, it can’t be reckoned or compared, it’s not even a fraction.”
sn56.52:4.9: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …
sn56.52:4.10: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
